DiscreteDists 1.0.0
  • Reference

The discrete Perks family

Source: R/DP.R
DP.Rd

The function DP() defines the discrete Perks distribution, a two parameter distribution, for a gamlss.family object to be used in GAMLSS fitting using the function gamlss().

DP(mu.link = "log", sigma.link = "log")

Arguments

mu.link

defines the mu.link, with "log" link as the default for the mu parameter.

sigma.link

defines the sigma.link, with "log" link as the default for the sigma.

Details

The discrete Perks distribution with parameters \(\mu > 0\) and \(\sigma > 0\) has a support 0, 1, 2, ... and density given by

\(f(x | \mu, \sigma) = \frac{\mu(1+\mu)(e^\sigma-1)e^{\sigma x}}{(1+\mu e^{\sigma x})(1+\mu e^{\sigma(x+1)})} \)

Note: in this implementation we changed the original parameters \(\lambda\) for \(\mu\) and \(\beta\) for \(\sigma\), we did it to implement this distribution within gamlss framework.

References

Tyagi, A., Choudhary, N., & Singh, B. (2020). A new discrete distribution: Theory and applications to discrete failure lifetime and count data. J. Appl. Probab. Statist, 15, 117-143.

See also

dDP.

Author

Veronica Seguro Varela, vseguro@unal.edu.co

Examples

# Example 1
# Generating some random values with
# known mu and sigma
set.seed(123)
y <- rDP(n=1000, mu=2.5, sigma=0.4)

# Fitting the model
library(gamlss)
mod1 <- gamlss(y~1, family=DP,
               control=gamlss.control(n.cyc=500, trace=TRUE))
#> GAMLSS-RS iteration 1: Global Deviance = 4134.723 

# Extracting the fitted values for mu and sigma
# using the inverse link function
exp(coef(mod1, what="mu"))
#> (Intercept) 
#>    2.283773 
exp(coef(mod1, what="sigma"))
#> (Intercept) 
#>   0.4095017 

# Example 2
# Generating random values under some model

# A function to simulate a data set with Y ~ DP
gendat <- function(n) {
  x1 <- runif(n)
  x2 <- runif(n)
  mu    <- exp(-1.6 + 5 * x1)
  sigma <- exp(1.7 - 5 * x2)
  y <- rDP(n=n, mu=mu, sigma=sigma)
  data.frame(y=y, x1=x1, x2=x2)
}

set.seed(123)
datos <- gendat(n=1000)

mod2 <- NULL
mod2 <- gamlss(y~x1, sigma.fo=~x2, family=DP, data=datos,
                 control=gamlss.control(n.cyc=500, trace=TRUE))
#> GAMLSS-RS iteration 1: Global Deviance = 4224.711 
#> GAMLSS-RS iteration 2: Global Deviance = 4224.711 

summary(mod2)
#> Warning: summary: vcov has failed, option qr is used instead
#> ******************************************************************
#> Family:  c("DP", "discrete-Perks") 
#> 
#> Call:  
#> gamlss(formula = y ~ x1, sigma.formula = ~x2, family = DP, data = datos,  
#>     control = gamlss.control(n.cyc = 500, trace = TRUE)) 
#> 
#> Fitting method: RS() 
#> 
#> ------------------------------------------------------------------
#> Mu link function:  log
#> Mu Coefficients:
#>              Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept) 1.501e+01  6.068e-01   24.73   <2e-16 ***
#> x1          1.575e-05  1.057e+00    0.00        1    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> ------------------------------------------------------------------
#> Sigma link function:  log
#> Sigma Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)   1.5924     0.0865   18.41   <2e-16 ***
#> x2           -5.2772     0.1438  -36.70   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> ------------------------------------------------------------------
#> No. of observations in the fit:  1000 
#> Degrees of Freedom for the fit:  4
#>       Residual Deg. of Freedom:  996 
#>                       at cycle:  2 
#>  
#> Global Deviance:     4224.711 
#>             AIC:     4232.711 
#>             SBC:     4252.342 
#> ******************************************************************

# Example 3
y <- rep(0:4, times=c(46, 76, 24, 9, 1))

# Fitting the model
library(gamlss)
mod3 <- gamlss(y~1, family=DP)
#> GAMLSS-RS iteration 1: Global Deviance = 376.2045 

# Extracting the fitted values for mu and sigma
# using the inverse link function
exp(coef(mod3, what="mu"))
#> (Intercept) 
#>  0.09047406 
exp(coef(mod3, what="sigma"))
#> (Intercept) 
#>    1.841804 

# Example 4
y <- rep(0:9, times=c(1, 2, 11, 20, 29, 23, 10, 3, 1, 0))

# Fitting the model
library(gamlss)
mod4 <- gamlss(y~1, family=DP)
#> GAMLSS-RS iteration 1: Global Deviance = 355.2735 

# Extracting the fitted values for mu and sigma
# using the inverse link function
exp(coef(mod4, what="mu"))
#> (Intercept) 
#> 0.003540372 
exp(coef(mod4, what="sigma"))
#> (Intercept) 
#>    1.244826 

# Example 5
y <- c(1, 3, 3, 6, 7, 7, 10, 12, 14, 15, 18,
       19, 22, 26, 28, 29, 34, 40, 48, 49)

# Fitting the model
library(gamlss)
mod4 <- gamlss(y~1, family=DP)
#> GAMLSS-RS iteration 1: Global Deviance = 157.6277 

# Extracting the fitted values for mu and sigma
# using the inverse link function
exp(coef(mod4, what="mu"))
#> (Intercept) 
#>   0.4440744 
exp(coef(mod4, what="sigma"))
#> (Intercept) 
#>  0.08419819
